text: last March scientists placed in the
Arctic Ocean a buoy to measure chemicals
in the atmosphere as part of a project
called a buoy the buoy contained
chemical analysis instruments along with
meteorological sensors a satellite
communication system batteries and solar
panels and a camera the buoy was
transported out to the ocean by an
icebreaker than lowered into the ice by
a helicopter the Oh buoy instruments
measure carbon dioxide ozone and bromine
oxide in arctic air carbon dioxide is a
greenhouse gas and ozone and bromine
oxide are key chemicals in Arctic
atmospheric chemistry because it is
difficult to collect data in the Arctic
not much is known about the
concentrations of these compounds in the
air how the concentrations change over
time how the chemicals react and the
role of sea water or ice in the
chemistry the buoys stay in place until
the ice melts after which they float in
the water they continue to collect data
until something happens to disable them
such as being toppled by a bump from a
chunk of ice
